content.user_title: Deploy Kafka on Kubernetes with Strimzi
content.value_statement: Setting up Apache Kafka on Kubernetes requires complex operator configuration, KRaft mode setup, and topic management. This skill provides production-ready YAML templates and step-by-step commands for deploying Kafka clusters using the Strimzi operator.
actual_capabilities: Install Strimzi operator on Kubernetes cluster
Configure production-ready 3-node Kafka clusters with KRaft
Create and manage Kafka topics via CRDs
Test producers and consumers with console tools
Enable Prometheus monitoring for Kafka clusters
limitations: Does not support managed Kafka services like Confluent Cloud or MSK
Requires existing Kubernetes cluster with kubectl access
Does not configure external load balancers or ingress

faq.question: Does this skill work with managed Kafka services?
faq.answer: No. This skill is for self-managed Kafka on Kubernetes using Strimzi. Use Confluent Cloud or MSK documentation for managed services.

faq.question: What Kubernetes versions are supported?
faq.answer: Strimzi supports Kubernetes 1.21 and later. Check Strimzi documentation for specific version compatibility.

faq.question: How does KRaft mode differ from ZooKeeper?
faq.answer: KRaft mode uses Kafka's internal Raft consensus instead of ZooKeeper, simplifying deployment and reducing operational complexity.

faq.question: Is my data safe when deleting clusters?
faq.answer: By default, persistent claims retain data. Set deleteClaim: true in storage config or manually delete PVCs to clean up.

faq.question: Why are my Kafka pods stuck in pending state?
faq.answer: Common causes include insufficient cluster resources, missing storage class, or node selector constraints. Check kubectl describe events for details.

faq.question: How does this compare to other Kafka deployment methods?
faq.answer: Strimzi provides Kubernetes-native deployment with CRDs. It offers better integration than manual deployment but less control than custom operators.
